feed.title: New on DVD
feed.subtitle: Among this week's new releases: Moneyball, Higher Ground, and the lovingly re-tooled The Magnificent Ambersons, Citizen Kane.

link.title: Moneyball

link.title: Review: Moneyball

link.Abstract: Boardwalk Empire enters its second season Sept. 25 with a confident Steve Buscemi at the helm.
link.title: Boardwalk Empire returns for second season with style and substance

link.Abstract: History will show 2011 as a year of technological and business-model transition.
link.title: Katherine Monk's Top 10 movies of 2011

content.div:
Moneyball: Three and a half stars out of five —Baseball movies are as close to the American ethos as apple pie and an aversion to paying taxes, so any type of tinkering with the romance of the great game could be considered downright seditious. That said, Brad Pitt remains a good symbol of American pride, so when he takes on the role of Oakland Athletics' general manager Billy Beane, and puts his faith in the decidedly unromantic form of Jonah Hill as a number-crunching genius, the movie finds an oddly compelling limp. Director Bennett Miller plays with the inherent diamond cliches, from the idea of the baseball "natural," to the notion of a game-saving play, but, thanks to this odd pace and dramatic phrasing, it feels surprisingly fresh. Pitt's on-camera chemistry is used with discretion, and the movie feels positively elegant, as it explores the land of Cracker Jack, overpriced beer and tepid hotdogs. Special features include Moneyball PS3 wallpaper, Brad Loses It blooper, Billy Beane: Re-inventing the Game, Moneyball: Playing the Game, Adapting Moneyball, ultraviolet streaming content and more.

Higher Ground: Three and a half stars out of five — There are scenes of baptism and prayer. The cameras roll behind pews and point at altars. But the central character in Higher Ground remains conspicuously absent. And so He should, because this directorial debut from latter-day A-lister, Vera Farmiga, is about one woman's quest to understand and embrace God. There is a gaping hole in the sacred heart of Corinne (Farmiga), a woman who accepted Jesus into her heart as a girl, but has second thoughts about her faith as a grown woman. Corinne did everything she was supposed to do — get married, have children, worship weekly — but she still feels empty. At least, that's the impression we get from watching Farmiga's pale blue eyes search the nooks and crannies of the empty space around her. She moves with an almost automatic gait, but whether this is a mirror of her mechanized faith or plain ennui isn't revealed with any certainty: Farmiga keeps the door of interpretation open, which was the only to play her loaded hand with any finesse. Special features include commentary, deleted scenes, making-of featurette and more.

The Magnificent Ambersons: Four stars out of five —Long considered the cinematic equivalent of a live lobotomy, the hatchet edit on Magnificent Ambersons was considered a legendary crime against art. After the studio demanded huge revisions, and director Orson Welles left town for Brazil, the footage ended up in the hands of Robert Wise (The Sound of Music). Wise was forced to cut several minutes, and, eventually, huge swaths of the original version, without Welles' approval. The resulting film felt half-finished, and because the edited portions were permanently lost, most cineastes figured this sophomore feature from the man who made Citizen Kane would never be whole again. This new cut can't be considered a true restoration, because some elements are gone forever, but it does give any Welles fan a great feeling for the kind of movie he was trying to make. A stylish examination of old money, new money and the arrogance of entitlement, The Magnificent Ambersons features the best work you'll ever see from Agnes Moorehead — who would (famously) go on to be Endora from Bewitched. Moorehead plays the interloping aunt Fanny, a jealous woman who tries to sabotage everyone else's happiness so she can feel better about herself. The production design is spectacular, the dialogue is rich, and the acting top notch, allowing plenty of room for forgiveness in the face of history's errors. Special features are a disappointment. There is none, except for subtitles in English and Spanish.

Citizen Kane: Five stars out of five — Yes, everyone likes to argue the merits of Citizen Kane. Some say it's the most overrated film ever made. Others see it as a groundbreaking, artistically realized piece of craftsmanship that encapsulates the biggest social shifts of the 20th century. Tackling everything from media ownership to megalomaniacal corporatism, Citizen Kane showed us a world in the midst of great change through the morally compromised lens of Charles Foster Kane — a man who lost touch with what mattered most in life, and in print: truth. A tragedy that continues to resonate, Citizen Kane remains a landmark of cinema, and probably the best film ever made. This new Blu-ray edition is collector-worthy, featuring a new 1080p digital transfer, created using original nitrate elements (original negative), separate commentaries, interview with Robert Wise, stills gallery, newsreel footage, and The Battle Over Citizen Kane, a 1995 Oscar-nominated documentary feature about the film.

1911: Two stars out of five — The Xinhai Revolution may be the most important event of the 20th century for toppling the Qing dynasty and recreating the fabric of China. Led by the humanistic force of Dr. Sun Yat-Sen (played here by Winston Chao), the event set the stage for a geopolitical recalibration that assumed democratic rule was the highest and most just form of government. One hundred years later, the dream of a democratic China remains unfulfilled, but the idea continues to linger in the Asian imagination. This film, created largely by committee, had a hard time coming to any overarching conclusions about the merits of the Revolution and the democratic ideal, and it suffers as a result. The romantic motivation of building a new nation can never be articulated with any conviction, and the characters feel limp and undefined as a result of the wishy-washy approach. Jackie Chan, who plays battle leader Huang Xing, is a relief to watch, but the martial-arts battle scenes feel entirely contrived to maximize his talents. A classic example of too many cooks spoiling the cinematic broth, 1911 fails to bring the spirit of revolution home to a new audience. Special features include on-set interviews with Jackie Chan and Li Bing Bing, making-of featurette, deleted scenes, TV spots and trailers and behind-the-scenes footage.

What's Your Number? One and a half stars out of five — Getting someone's number these days isn't what it used to be. Sure, you can still get someone's digits and dial them up. But in pop-culture-speak, your "number" is short for the number of sexual conquests you've recorded. What? You find that vulgar and tasteless? You mean discussing the number of sexual partners you've exchanged fluids with feels a little rancid to the soul? If so, then you probably won't find too much to love in this unfathomably bad Anna Faris movie about a gal trying to keep her number down so she doesn't look too slutty. To keep it low, she dates old boyfriends in the hopes of finding a new treasure in the chaff. Silly, insulting and frequently in poor taste, this film destroys everything it touches — including the comically gifted Faris and the laid-back charm of co-star Chris Evans. Special DVD features include extended cut, deleted dates and a gag reel.

Boardwalk Empire: Season 1: Four stars out of five — If you haven't caught up with Nucky Thompson yet, here's your chance to take in the first season of HBO's awards magnet about a plucky guy named Nucky, and his bid to be the boss of the boardwalk. When this Prohibition-era production hit the airwaves, a lot of people felt it may be a bloated failure. The pilot was the most expensive chunk of TV ever produced, but because it was directed by heavyweight Martin Scorsese, the skeptical gave it the benefit of the doubt. They haven't made a peep since, because the show has found fans just about everywhere, thanks to its elaborate production, involving a full-scale build of old Atlantic City, as well as the top-notch cast lead by Steve Buscemi and great writing from Sopranos alumnus, Terence Winter. This first season is available in several types of packaging, including one that has a T-shirt, and another that includes your very own Boardwalk Empire whiskey flask.

Also released Jan. 10:

American Graffiti, Blu-ray

An Idiot Abroad

Billy Elliot, Blu-ray

Breakfast Club, Blu-ray

Columbo Mystery Movie Collection

Coronation Street, Vol. 3

Dennis the Menace

Doctor Who, Invasion of the Dinosaurs

Imitation of Life

North by Northwest

Hawaii Five-0, The Final Season

Nevermind, 20th Anniversary Tribute

Scorpion King 3

The Tempest

There Be Dragons

kmonk@postmedia.com

Twitter.com/katherinemonk

link.Abstract: Mad Men made history Sunday at the 63rd Primetime Emmy Awards in Los Angeles - history both good and not-so-good.
link.title: Emmys keep winners in the family

link.Abstract: In the comedy awards, Modern Family won a total of five awards. The major drama acting awards went instead to Kyle Chandler for Friday Night Lights, and Julianna Margulies for The Good Wife.
link.title: Modern Family cleans up at Emmys

link.Abstract: Boardwalk Empire, HBO’s fact-based Prohibiton era drama starring Steve Buscemi as Atlantic City criminal kingpin Enoch "Nucky" Thompson, has served early notice that it is the show to beat at next weekend’s Primetime Emmy Awards.
link.title: Boardwalk Empire collects seven early Emmys
